questions.question_text:
The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) for an organization wants to develop custom IDS rulesets faster, prior to new rules being released by IDS vendors.
Which of the following BEST meets this objective?

choices.A: Identify a third-party source for IDS rules and change the configuration on the applicable IDSs to pull in the new rulesets
choices.B: Encourage cybersecurity analysts to review open-source intelligence products and threat database to generate new IDS rules based on those sources
choices.C: Leverage the latest TCP- and UDP-related RFCs to arm sensors and IDSs with appropriate heuristics for anomaly detection
choices.D: Use annual hacking conventions to document the latest attacks and threats, and then develop IDS rules to counter those threats

comments.content:
If anyone's interested in what Open Source Threat Intelligence looks like, I've been using the blacklists at emerging threats on my home network for years
https://rules.emergingthreats.net/fwrules/emerging-Block-IPs.txt
(Note: I am not affiliated with this company in any way and do not endorse their products professionally, I am only pointing out a real life example of Open Source Threat Intelligence that could be applicable for comprehension of this answer).

TheSkyMan is right. RFCs aren't where heuristics or detection algorithms are created or shared. The place to find the latest and greatest threat detection standards and tools, would be open source threat intelligence.

discussion.content:
It's easy to get hung up on fancy words like heuristics and anomaly detection. RFCs are for things like developing new protocols or standards; they're not applicable in this situation. Answer is B.

https://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/Request-for-Comments-RFC

Will OSS help generate rulesets faster than commercial sources? If so, why use a commercial source? How could commercial sources stay in business?
I like OSS, I am on a linux box right now. But it's surprising the IDS vendor would lag behind OSS sources. If that were the case, why wouldn't the commercial IDS vendor use the OSS sources?

Compare to question # 129

Maybe: A. Identify a third-party source for IDS rules and change the configuration on the applicable IDSs to pull in the new rulesets ?

A third service updates continually. You can configure the IDS to check your third party source every hour.

B. Encourage cybersecurity analysts to review open-source intelligence products and threat database to generate new IDS rules based on those sources

Great, if your cybersecurity analysts have nothing else to do.

C. Leverage the latest TCP- and UDP-related RFCs to arm sensors and IDSs with appropriate heuristics for anomaly detection

As TheSkyMan posted: RFCs are for things like developing new protocols or standards; they're not applicable in this situation. 

D. Use annual hacking conventions to document the latest attacks and threats, and then develop IDS rules to counter those threats

How often will such conventions be attended? Once a year? Maybe once ever six months?
Which TCP and UDP-related RFCs? And I'm pretty sure that those don't get update all too often. Answer should be "B".

A. Identify – Takes time.
B. Review – Takes time.
C. Heuristics and Anomaly Detection. – Real Time.
D. Document – Takes time.

Faster and before a vendor release. I think the correct answer is C.

comments.content:
Answer A does really take time. 
A. Identify a third-party source for IDS rules and change the configuration on the applicable IDSs to pull in the new rulesets
Once set up, the company would be using a third party to update it's IDS ruleset. 
Answer B could be incredibly time consuming.

discussion.content: C. Translation - use existing network traffic baselines to teach your IDS systems what is abnormal and then setting policies to detect anomalies.

Selected Answer: A
I wanted to go with D but there are a lot of resources that state IPSs fail at stopping DDOS attacks. I went with A because of different sources published from Cisco and others, including a cert guide:
Remotely Triggered Black Hole (RTBH) filtering is a technique that uses routing protocol updates to manipulate route tables at the network edge, or anywhere else in the network, specifically to drop undesirable traffic before it enters the service provider network.
One major area that needs to be mitigated is distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks. For DDoS protection, once an attack is detected, black holing can be used to drop all DDoS attack traffic at the edge of an Internet service provider (ISP) network, based on either the destination or source IP address. Black holing is done by forwarding this traffic to a Null0 interface.

Selected Answer: A
I eliminated B&C right away, because of cynical "enrollment" statement and WAF, respectively. "C" cannot be the answer, WAF is designed to protect a web app, not stop DDoS. 

Now, I go with "A" because null route would stop DDoS and working on RTBH is a long-term strategy, more viable than relying on IPS to stop DDoS. I don't know why, at our level which is CASP+, people still talk about IPS for DDoS prevention - that is not correct, and I will reference this article: https://blog.radware.com/security/2013/05/can-firewall-and-ips-block-ddos-attacks/

Another bad question with horrible solutions, but I pick A.

The answer should be A. 
The objective is to fix the issue for the next 4 hours. So the engineer should route the inbound web traffic to Null Interface. 
"D" tells to purchase an IPS to prevent DDoS which is not right.

D. The ISP engineer should begin refusing network connections to the web server immediately to restore Internet connectivity on campus. The university should purchase an IPS device to stop DDoS attacks in the future.

Probably the best of these bad choices. The IPS would protect the server, and restore service. Need to accept the server being down until the IPS can be purchased and set up.

C. The ISP engineer should immediately begin blocking IP addresses that are attacking the web server to restore Internet connectivity. In the future, the university should install a WAF to prevent this attack from happening again.

Seems like spoofed IPs are being generated at random, at a rate of hundreds or thousands per second. You would be playing whack-a-mole trying to stop individual IPs.

A. The ISP engineer should null route traffic to the web server immediately to restore Internet connectivity. The university should implement a remotely triggered black hole with the ISP to resolve this more quickly in the future.

This would shut the attack down and restore service, but your server is useless.

A = C = D = Shut off the server? 
At least in the short term, it seems to me that any of those choices do the same thing: shut off all access to the server. 
As to C: the only way to block "IP addresses attacking the server" would be to shut down all connections. There is no pattern to the IP address accessing the web server. Although C may give the best long term solution.
Could B possibly be an answer? Hard to imagine that thousands of legit users would want to access the server in a second, which seems to be the case
D is the right answer. The ISP can throw an ACL in to look at the source port for every originating IP address going to the web server IP address and block anything trying to talk inbound.

C
The ISP should block the DDoS IPs and a WAF protects your server against DDoS attacks. If you were going with D you might as well just unplug the server (why didn't you just turn it off if we're going to blacklist the SERVER???)

comments.content: WAFs can block based on rate
Having trouble understanding, what part exactly indicates that they are attacking at a rate of thousands per second?
Is that really feasible? There is no pattern to the IP addresses that are attacking. And they are attacking at a rate of thousands per second.

choices.B: A university web server is under increased load during enrollment. The ISP engineer should immediately increase bandwidth to 2Gbps to restore Internet connectivity. In the future, the university should pay for more bandwidth to handle spikes in web server traffic.
choices.D: The ISP engineer should begin refusing network connections to the web server immediately to restore Internet connectivity on campus. The university should purchase an IPS device to stop DDoS attacks in the future.
choices.C: The ISP engineer should immediately begin blocking IP addresses that are attacking the web server to restore Internet connectivity. In the future, the university should install a WAF to prevent this attack from happening again.
choices.A: The ISP engineer should null route traffic to the web server immediately to restore Internet connectivity. The university should implement a remotely triggered black hole with the ISP to resolve this more quickly in the future.

discussion.content: Why wouldn’t “B” be an option for a new CISO in terms of getting the lay of the land in this new industry s/he’s entering. Conduct an audit and see how compliant the company is. Does this make sense? If not, why not?

Why wouldn’t “B” be an option for a new CISO in terms of getting the lay of the land in this new industry s/he’s entering. Conduct an audit and see how compliant the company is. Does this make sense? If not, why not?

comments.content: Said, whom? No part of the question stated anything about "cost-effectiveness" or "no budget" - therefore, everything is on the table, including hiring 3rd party consultant.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
For me it is D and E.
It is unlikely the CISO will have the resources to conduct a pentest, audit or hire a third-party just starting a new position in a new industry
But he can define a threat model from Industry threats and existing BIA.

comments.content: Hiring a third party consultant seems to be more about who the work is assigned to, as opposed to what work is being done.

The BIA does not identify relevant risks, it just describes what the impact on the business would be if certain things were to happen. I suppose that is somewhat related, but not very directly. 
By contrast, threat modeling, seems to be the very definition of finding relevant risks.

Although a CISO should have technical knowledge, I don't think a CISO is necessarily capable of doing a pentest. Or what if were pentesting at the beginning of there career and haven't done it in a decade? Just seems very unlikely that a CISO would be doing something that technically involved. I don't think A is the answer.

discussion.content: I think A and E. Hiring a third party consultant doesnt seem right. He has just been hired to do this job, why would the company then allow him to hire someone else to do it.

Maybe: A. Perform a penetration test?
A pentest can reveal undiscovered vulnerabilities. To know where you are vulnerable is to know where you are at risk.

Maybe: D. Define the threat model?
Maybe not: E. Review the existing BIA?

I think a risk is threat + vulnerability.

The BIA does not identify relevant risks, it just describes what the impact on the business would be if certain things were to happen. I suppose that is somewhat related, but not very directly. 

Defining the threat model seems more directly relevant.

Wikipedia: "Threat modeling is a process by which potential threats, such as structural vulnerabilities or the absence of appropriate safeguards, can be identified, enumerated, and mitigations can be prioritized. The purpose of threat modeling is to provide defenders with a systematic analysis of what controls or defenses need to be included, given the nature of the system, the probable attacker's profile, the most likely attack vectors, and the assets most desired by an attacker. Threat modeling answers questions like “Where am I most vulnerable to attack?”, “What are the most relevant threats?”, and “What do I need to do to safeguard against these threats?”."

 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threat_model

While reviewing the IDS logs, the engineer can view the outbound callback traffic, but sees no traffic between the two computers.

questions.question_text: As part of incident response, a technician is taking an image of a compromised system and copying the image to a remote image server (192.168.45.82). The system drive is very large but does not contain the sensitive data. The technician has limited time to complete this task. Which of the following is the BEST command for the technician to run?

discussion.content: The correct answer is D. You can use the dd and nc commands for exact disk mirroring from one server to another. It is more explained here: https://www.linuxjournal.com/content/tech-tip-remote-mirroring-using-nc-and-dd

comments.content: Reread the question. where does it say securely copy?

discussion.content: nc = NetCat, spc = Secure Copy. If the goal is to securely copy drive image should you pipe your command to NetCat? This looks like a simple matter of knowing basic commands. It's not a Linux test so don't overthink it.

Maybe: D. dd if=/dev/sda | nc 192.168.45.82 3000 is correct?
Tech Tip: Remote Mirroring Using nc and dd 
https://www.linuxjournal.com/content/tech-tip-remote-mirroring-using-nc-and-dd

comments.content:
Because B is not copying the drive, only memory. 
B. dd if=/dev/mem
D. dd if=/dev/sda

Then again, when I re-reread the question, I notice no indication the entire drive needs to be imaged. The question states: "a technician is taking an image of a compromised system." That might not mean the entire drive. In fact, the question also states: "The system drive is very large but does not contain the sensitive data." Since the tech is pressed for time, and system drive does not contain the sensitive data, maybe B would make more sense.
order of volatility in an IR situation. agreed. i would choose B too.
That's my logic. Going with B.

discussion.content: if the system drive is very large but does not contain the sensitive data why not do B? I'm not sure about this one...

Since you are making an image, you want to use the dd command. Also, since you are making an image you would have to specify a drive. That means the only command that even starts out correctly is: dd if=/dev/sda . . .

I have never seen the dd command used in this manner, and see no reason to do so. But, I suppose, it's the most plausible answer.
